title: 113_hr2574
content: The "Keep Student Loans Affordable Act of 2013" extends the interest rate deadline to July 1, 2014, amending the Higher Education Act of 1965. Additionally, modifications are made to required distribution rules for pension plans. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to require distribution of an employee's interest within 5 years of their death, unless payable to an eligible designated beneficiary. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires distribution of an employee's interest within 5 years of their death, unless payable to an eligible designated beneficiary. If certain conditions are met, the distribution can be spread over the life expectancy of the beneficiary, with distributions starting within 1 year of the employee's death. There is a special rule for surviving spouses. The special rule for surviving spouses of employees states that distributions must begin no earlier than when the employee would have turned 70 1/2. If the surviving spouse dies before receiving distributions, the rule is applied as if the spouse were the employee. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amends the definition of an eligible designated beneficiary as any individual designated by the employee to receive distributions from the employee's interest. If the designated beneficiary dies before the distribution is complete, the remaining portion must be distributed within 5 years after the beneficiary's death. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines an eligible designated beneficiary as the surviving spouse, a minor child, a disabled individual, or a chronically ill individual of the deceased employee. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines an eligible designated beneficiary as the surviving spouse, a minor child, a disabled individual, or a chronically ill individual of the deceased employee. A special rule applies to children who cease to be eligible designated beneficiaries upon reaching majority age. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions for employees becoming 5-percent owners after age 70 1/2. The amendments made by this section apply to distributions with respect to employees who die after December 31, 2013. The amendment applies to employees becoming 5-percent owners for plan years ending in calendar years before, on, or after the enactment date. Special rules apply for employees becoming 5-percent owners before 2013 and not retiring before 2014. Exception for beneficiaries of employees who die before 2014 but after 2013. The amendments made by this section apply to beneficiaries of designated beneficiaries who die after December 31, 2013. The designated beneficiary will be treated as an eligible designated beneficiary for applying section 401(a)(9)(B)(iv) of the Code. An exception is made for existing annuity contracts that were in effect before the enactment of this Act and remain binding. A qualified annuity contract refers to a commercial annuity or one payable by a defined benefit plan. An eligible designated beneficiary for a qualified annuity contract is one where annuity payments are made over the lives of the employee and a designated beneficiary, in accordance with specific regulations. The annuity payments must have begun before January 1, 2014, and meet the requirements of section 401(a)(9) of the Code. An eligible designated beneficiary for a qualified annuity contract must have made an irrevocable election before a specific date regarding the method and amount of annuity payments to the employee or designated beneficiaries.
